title: 303 Redirect Checker
metaTitle: Free 303 Redirect Checker | Test See Other Redirects
metaDescription: Check 303 See Other redirects used after form submissions. Verify proper POST-to-GET conversion and ensure correct redirect implementation.
heroDescription: Verify 303 See Other redirects that convert POST requests to GET. Essential for form submissions and preventing duplicate submissions.

children.text: A 303 'See Other' redirect explicitly converts POST requests to GET requests, directing the browser to retrieve the resource using GET. Unlike
which may or may not change the method, 303 guarantees POST-to-GET conversion. This is the standard way to redirect after successful form submissions to prevent duplicate submissions on page refresh.
The primary use case for 303 redirects is the Post/Redirect/Get (PRG) pattern:
Server responds with 303 redirect to confirmation page
Browser makes GET request to confirmation page
If the user refreshes the page, the browser repeats the GET request instead of resubmitting the form, preventing duplicate orders, payments, or submissions.
303: Always converts POST to GET (use after form submissions)
: May convert POST to GET (legacy behavior)
: Preserves POST method (use when POST must remain POST)
303 redirects don't pass link equity and aren't typically used for SEO purposes. They're functional redirects for user experience. For SEO-related redirects during

faqs.question: What is a 303 See Other redirect?
faqs.answer: A 303 redirect explicitly tells the browser to retrieve the redirected resource using GET, regardless of the original request method. It's primarily used after POST form submissions to redirect to a confirmation page, preventing duplicate submissions when users refresh the page.

faqs.question: Why use 303 instead of 302 for form redirects?
faqs.answer: 303 explicitly guarantees POST-to-GET conversion, while 302's behavior is ambiguous - some browsers might preserve POST, others convert to GET. For the Post/Redirect/Get pattern, 303 is the correct, unambiguous choice that all modern browsers handle consistently.

faqs.question: Do 303 redirects affect SEO?
faqs.answer: No, 303 redirects don't pass link equity and aren't meant for SEO purposes. They're functional redirects for user experience, specifically preventing duplicate form submissions. For SEO-related redirects, use 301 or 308 permanent redirects instead.

faqs.question: When should I use 303 redirects?
faqs.answer: Use 303 redirects after processing POST requests when you want to redirect to a confirmation page using GET. Common use cases include form submissions, checkout completions, payment confirmations, and any situation where you need to prevent duplicate submissions on page refresh.

faqs.question: What is the Post/Redirect/Get pattern?
faqs.answer: Post/Redirect/Get (PRG) is a web development pattern that prevents duplicate form submissions. After processing a POST request, the server sends a 303 redirect to a GET endpoint. If the user refreshes, the browser repeats the harmless GET request instead of resubmitting the form.

faqs.question: Can I use 303 for API redirects?
faqs.answer: 303 is rarely used for APIs because it converts POST to GET, which may not be desired behavior. For API redirects that must preserve methods, use 307 (temporary) or 308 (permanent). Use 303 primarily for browser-based form submissions.

faqs.question: Do all browsers support 303 redirects?
faqs.answer: All modern browsers properly support 303 redirects and handle the POST-to-GET conversion correctly. Very old browsers might not recognize 303 and may treat it as a generic 300-level redirect. For modern web applications, 303 is safe to use.

faqs.question: Should e-commerce sites use 303 redirects?
faqs.answer: Yes, e-commerce sites should use 303 redirects after checkout to prevent duplicate orders. When a customer completes a purchase, redirect them with 303 to the order confirmation page. If they refresh, only the confirmation page reloads, not the payment processing.

faqs.question: How do I implement a 303 redirect?
faqs.answer: Implementation depends on your platform. In Express.js use res.redirect(303, '/confirmation'), in PHP use header('HTTP/1.1 303 See Other') then header('Location: /confirmation'). Always test with our 303 redirect checker to verify correct implementation.

faqs.question: What happens if I don't use 303 after POST?
faqs.answer: Without a redirect after POST, refreshing the page triggers the browser's 'confirm form resubmission' dialog, and users may accidentally resubmit forms, creating duplicate orders, emails, or database entries. Using 303 redirects eliminates this problem by converting to safe GET requests.
